page.title: 11Ecology of Morchard Bishop
page.content: This is an area patterned with small fields surrounded by hedge banks, streams with trees along them and pockets of woodland.Small birds,both resident and migrant are plentiful. Rooks abound with a rookery at Venn. There are many magpies and crows.This year saw few swallows and housemartins and the cuckoo was hardly heard.Canada geese and buzzards nest in the old quarry,our only truly 'wild place'. Winter visitors are plovers,starlings, and fieldfares.Pheasants,partridges, hares and little owls exist in small numbers.Badgers and foxes are plentiful and rabbits back again in number.Both fallow and red deer are occasionaly seen.Butterflies are rare. 1985 started exceptionaly cold and dry and in late July turned cold and wet.Part of the village in now a conservation area.
